title: Confirm Te (Dominant)
intro: Answer based on long-term patterns across years and contexts. Use 4–5 only if it’s consistently true. Te-dominant is self-determination through the objective world: making decisions by external evidence, building workable systems, and pushing reality to run better (results, coordination, execution).

items.text: When something doesn’t work, I feel an urge to fix it in the real world (process, plan, responsibilities), not just analyze it endlessly.
examples: I naturally ask: “What’s the bottleneck and what’s the next action?”
I get impatient when a problem stays unresolved because no one decides.
I prefer moving a plan forward over perfect conceptual clarity.
I’ll take a workable solution now over a beautiful idea later.

items.text: I evaluate ideas by outcomes and evidence. If results contradict the story, I adjust the story.
examples: I care about what can be measured, verified, or observed.
I’m willing to change my view quickly when data shows it.
I dislike decisions based purely on vibes or personal preference.
I ask: “What’s the proof this works?”

items.text: I naturally organize people/resources/time to make things run smoothly. It feels normal to assign, schedule, and coordinate.
examples: I create structure (priorities, deadlines, roles) without being asked.
When others are vague, I try to make it concrete and actionable.
I often end up being the ‘driver’ just because I want progress.
I notice inefficiencies and want to streamline them.

items.text: I prefer clear decisions and closure. Keeping options open for too long feels like wasted time or risk.
examples: I’d rather choose and adjust than stay indecisive.
I like checklists, milestones, or ‘done’ states.
I get annoyed when discussion loops without a decision.
I feel calmer when there is a plan and ownership.

items.text: I can be direct about problems, priorities, or performance. I see it as responsibility, not personal attack.
examples: I state what needs to happen even if it’s uncomfortable.
I’m okay with setting standards and holding people to them.
I dislike sugarcoating that hides the real issue.
I focus on the task even when emotions are present.

items.text: People sometimes label me as blunt, controlling, or ‘too results-focused,’ especially when I’m trying to prevent chaos or failure.
examples: Others say I push too hard for efficiency.
I’m sensitive to being seen as bossy when I’m just trying to get clarity.
I’ve been told I ‘don’t relax’ until things are handled.
I’ve been criticized for prioritizing outcomes over feelings.

items.text: I rarely take initiative to organize or lead; I prefer waiting, exploring, or staying flexible without plans.
examples: I dislike scheduling/coordination and avoid it when possible.
I don’t care much about closure or deadlines.
I prefer talking/imagining over executing.
I’m fine when nobody is ‘in charge’ for long periods.

items.text: I feel stuck or anxious when I must decide quickly; I prefer to keep thinking and refining rather than committing.
examples: I delay decisions because I fear choosing wrong.
I get lost in nuance and struggle to conclude.
I avoid setting firm priorities because it feels restrictive.
I’d rather keep options open than lock a plan.

items.text: I often soften facts to avoid hurting people; interpersonal impact is a higher priority than efficiency or results.
examples: I hesitate to give clear feedback if it might upset someone.
I prefer harmony over pushing for higher performance.
I avoid enforcing standards because it feels harsh.
I’d rather be kind than be bluntly accurate.

items.text: I trust my internal logic more than external systems, metrics, or ‘best practices’; I resist being judged by objective criteria.
examples: I dislike KPI-style thinking and feel it misses what matters.
I prefer perfect reasoning over practical usefulness.
I reject methods that work if they feel conceptually ugly.
I argue based on internal consistency more than outcomes.
